history.text: Hello
I didn't know that they had someone else sing instead of using the same actress for the speaking 5 year old Anna
Yes, I still enjoyed the movie though. The singing was pretty good.
The animation was really great as well. I really got lost in the movie.
In some ways, it does remind me of Beauty and the Beast, the Little Mermaid and other earlier movies.
Yes, that is definitely true. It is a great family movie that a whole family can enjoy of all ages.
I really enjoyed the reindeer in the movie. So cute.
I love that it was based on Hans Christian Andersen.  I just wish that more parents knew how to relate new movies back to the classics to show their children that the classics are still relevant.
Definitely. I give the movie 5 stars.
I agree.  The CinemaScore was A+, and that's wonderful.  I don't think that the Metacritic score of 74/100 was high enough.
Yes, definitely should have been higher.
Idina Menzel was a stunning choice for Elsa, but do you think Kristen Bell was bold enough for Anna?
Yes, Kristen did a great job.
I enjoyed the bits of comedy in the movie.
I loved the magic in it.
I did have a few issues with the movie.  The concept that parents would choose to hide things from one sister, to the point of erasing her memory, is scary to children.
Yes, but they can always watch the movie again when they get older and then they might understand it better.
It's a great fantasy film.
I also think that seeing two sisters so estranged is setting up some children for issues.
Yes, but it does reflect upon real life as well as fantasy.
And when a child sees that someone suppresses an issue instead of dealing with it, it's not a healthy coping mechanism
True. I agree.
At least she was healed though.
I'm glad she tried to control her magic.
I hated that Anna supposedly fell in love in one night.
It was sad indeed that the parents died.
Well at least she tried.
I understand having the parents die when the girls were teens.  While sad, they weren't integral to the plot.
Yes. They were just a small part of the movie.
It's hard to believe it has been 5 years since it's release, seems like only yesterday

I liked that they chose something out of fantasy (Elsa's magic) as the focus of discrimination.  It allows every child to see that discrimination can be about anything, and it allows them to learn to sympathize and empathize in a way that won't scare them.
Yes, the movie has great lessons.
I thought the trolls were a little silly.
I thought the castle was really beautiful.
I liked that accidents were treated as accidents, not as things done on purpose.  I also liked that there was no difference between whether the problem was accidental or on purpose
Yes, I enjoyed those parts of the movie.
It does have some scary parts though. Gave me a little anxiety during the film.
I can understand how parts scare children, especially when Hans lies about Elsa killing Anna.
Yes, I had a hard time with that. Mind games are never a good thing.
I also think the trolls were very silly.  But very young children could learn lessons from them more easily than they could from the more serious characters.
At least the movie had some adventure. I don't expect every movie to be perfect and go as one hopes.
Yes, the trolls were pleasing.
I agree with that estimation.  I loved that they phrased it as "an act of true love" without specifying
